briefdescription.para: Function pointer to particle bcond function is now called perodicitypptr.
Function pointer to position bcond function is now called perodicityxptr.
Function pointer to potential functions is now called potentialptr.

memberdef.type: void(*)(ui, std::vector< ui > &, std::vector< ldf > &, void *)
memberdef.name: extforceptr

briefdescription.para: Function pointer to external force functions is now called extforceptr.
Function pointer to external force functions is now called extforceptr.

inbodydescription.para: This function is designed to give the user an overview of the compilation
Computes the dot product of A[] and B[], assumed to both be of size dim.
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has no boundary conditions.
This function does nothing
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has no boundary conditions.
This function does nothing
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has periodic boundary conditions.

Checks if particle i has crossed the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, shifts its coordinate in that dimension by multiples of simbox.L[d] so that it is within the bounds (-simbox.L[d]/2,simbox.L[d]/2).
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has periodic boundary conditions.

Checks if point x is outside the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, shifts its coordinate in that dimension by multiples of simbox.L[d] so that it is within the bounds (-simbox.L[d]/2,simbox.L[d]/2).
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has hard boundary conditions.

Checks if particle i has crossed the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, updates its position and velocity to respect a hard wall reflection. The particle position is mirrored across the boundary wall, whereas its velocity component perpendicular to the boundary wall is reversed. This function correctly takes into account skewed boundary conditions, and uses the box matrices simbox.Lshear and simbox.vshear to calculate the reflections if simbox.useLshear is true.
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has hard boundary conditions.

Checks if point x is outside the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, updates its position to respect a hard wall reflection. The particle position is mirrored across the boundary wall. This function correctly takes into account skewed boundary conditions, and uses the box matrices simbox.Lshear and simbox.vshear to calculate the reflections if simbox.useLshear is true.
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has sheared boundary conditions.

Checks if particle i has crossed the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, updates its position and velocity according to the box shear matrices stored in simbox.Lshear and simbox.vshear. The particle position
Periodicity function to be called if dimension d has sheared boundary conditions.

Checks if point x is outside the boundary perpendicular to dimension d and, if so, updates its position according to the box shear matrices stored in simbox.Lshear and simbox.vshear. The particle position

Coulomb potential: \[V_{\text{COULOMB}}(r)=\frac{q}{r}\] This function depends on one parameter:
The charge coupling between two partilces: $q$

Yukawa potential: \[V_{\text{YUKAWA}}(r)=\frac{b}{r e^{kr}}\] This function depends on two parameters:
the coupling strength between two partilces $b$
the Yukawa reciprocal length scale $k$

Hookian potential (Harmonic spring potential): \[V_{\text{HOOKEAN}}(r)=\tfrac{1}{2}k{(r-r_0)}^2\] This function depends on two parameters:
the spring constant $k$
the spring's rest length $r_0$

The famous Lenard-Jones potential: \[V_{\text{LJ}}(r)=4 \epsilon \left({\left( \frac{\sigma}{r} \right)}^{12} - {\left( \frac{\sigma}{r} \right)}^6 \right) \] This function depends on two parameters:
the coupling constant $\epsilon$
the characteristic length scale $\sigma$

Morse potential: \[V_{\text{MORSE}}(r)=d{\left(1-e^{a(r_e-r)}\right)}^2\] This function depends on three parameters:
the dissociation energy $d$
the width $a$
the equilibrium bond distance $r_e$

Anharmoninc spring: \[V_{\text{ANHARMONICSPRING}}(r)=\tfrac{k}{\alpha}{\lvert r-r_0 \rvert}^{\alpha}\] This function depends on three parameters:
the 'spring' constant $k$
the 'spring' rest length $r_0$
the exponent $\alpha$

briefdescription.para: Fill an array with Gaussian distributed random variables ( $\mu=0$, $\sigma=1$)

inbodydescription.para: This function fills noise[dim] with random Gaussian variables (provided noise[dim] exists). The seed can be set by the second argument seed which has default value 0U (which is neglected) To set the seed call noise_gen<dim>(nullptr,seed) By the default the seed is randomly set by the random device

memberdef.argsstring: (ui i, std::vector< ui > &particles, std::vector< ldf > &parameters, void *sys)
memberdef.name: DAMPING

inbodydescription.para:
This external damping force takes the form: \[F^{\mu}_{\text{DAMPING}}(\dot{x}^{\mu})=-\gamma \dot{x}^{\mu}\] This function depends on one parameter:
the damping constant $\gamma$

memberdef.argsstring: (ui i, std::vector< ui > &particles, std::vector< ldf > &parameters, void *sys)
memberdef.name: DISSIPATION

inbodydescription.para:
This external dissipation force takes the form: \[F^{\mu}_{\text{DISSIPATION}}(\dot{x}^{\mu})=b \dot{x}_j^{\mu} - \dot{x}_i^{\mu}\] Here the jth particle is given in the particles std::vector This function depends on one parameter:
the damping constant $b$

memberdef.argsstring: (ui i, std::vector< ui > &particles, std::vector< ldf > &parameters, void *sys)
memberdef.name: LANGEVIN

inbodydescription.para:
This external Langevin force takes the form: \[F^{\mu}_{\text{LANGEVIN}}(\dot{x}^{\mu})=\sqrt{\left(2 \gamma k_B T\right)} \hat{\xi}(t)\] This function depends on one parameter:
the temperature $k_B T$
the damping constant $\gamma$

memberdef.argsstring: (ui i, std::vector< ui > &particles, std::vector< ldf > &parameters, void *sys)
memberdef.name: LANGEVIN_MP

briefdescription.para: Thermal noise with curvature external force functions.

inbodydescription.para:
This external Langevin force takes the form: \[F^{\mu}_{\text{LANGEVIN}}(\dot{x}^{\mu})=\sqrt{\left(2 \gamma k_B T\right)} \hat{\xi}(t)\] This function depends on one parameter:
the temperature $k_B T$
the damping constant $\gamma$
Kronecker delta function: \begin{align}\delta_{ij}=\begin{cases} 1 &\quad i=j\\0&\quad i \neq j\end{cases}\end{align}
The trivial Monge patch: \[f(x^{\rho})_{\text{FLATSPACE}} = 0 \] This function disregards all parameters.

The Gaussian bump Monge patch: \[f(x^{\rho})_{\text{GAUSSIANBUMP}} = A e^{-K x^{\rho}x^{\rho}}\] This function depends on two parameters:
the bump amplitude $A$
the bump width $K$ </li
